review_title: A decent gig for most any part of life, if you want it.
pros:
Flexibility can be fantastic, the benefits are up there besides food/bev and 401k match. Dental is at least okay in most locales. Overall, the ethos is sound and the culture works as intended. Everyone is empowered to do something meaningful and the support system is strong enough to appreciate in and out of work.

Making surprisingly meaningful connections in your community is nearly a given. There's room for growth if you can find where people are not locked in, where new stores might open. The friends you may make could easily last a lifetime if you wanted them to.

Despite the possible derision of working food and bev (pandemic or not)--it's easy to feel mostly proud of even the simplest work one can do as the company takes immense pains to appreciate what it has built. From the Grounds to Garden program to having an entire day dedicated to addressing unconscious bias in response to a racial profiling incident on the other side of the country--there's a lot of people who genuinely love their jobs and actively seek to get others to that place.
cons:
Experience can be extremely inconsistent amongst even neighboring stores (and this does not refer to licensed locations such as those in supermarkets &c.). It makes absolute sense why the company's pushed against unionizing when you see the decisions being made in some states. 

Changes to routines come somewhat frequently and have been poorly explained or justified in any regard. Products come and go with sometimes no notice (or the entire alcohol concept, for instance). It can be frustrating constantly having to overextend for the customers who lose their favorites orders unexpectedly, or for partners who have difficulty adapting to arbitrary micromanagement.

Probably not a good job for people unable to tolerate repetition, especially in a drive-through scenario. As with any business with that paradigm, semi-automated metrics on times are valued above actual results of service and sales--this overly corporate approach can cascade into the morale of people on both sides of the windows. [As such,] be ready to explain how real life works against corporate expectations from management dropped in with nary a week of context in de facto operations to refuse understanding why or how variations on routine exist (especially for care in health concerns for literally any relevant party).

pros: Most every coworker that I've ever had at any store was super friendly and easy to get along with. The general vibe between coworkers is great and you truly do meet lots of friends through the job.
cons: The company expects way too much from you and it's it or miss with store managers. Starbucks wants you to connect with the customer on a personal level but also get drinks out in record time? And then get upset with the baristas when customers do not rate us highly on our customer connection score -- which is scored in an entirely arbitrary way that means nothing at all. I could go on forever about the stupid customer connection score. Anyways, in my 4 years I've had 6 different store managers and they vary greatly. Managers who have worked their way up from barista are the best and truly understand the pain of being a barista. My last manager was an outside hire and only cared about climbing the corporate latter. Very fake attitude and it hard to work with. They spent most of their time spewing fake positivity which just annoyed all the partners and many customers too. Customers and ever our district manager could tell it was all an act. They were very good with scheduling though, I will give them that.

pros: you'll meet some incredible ppl, specifically coworkers and customers
cons: management sucks, they say they care for you and then micromanage

pros: Great perks and benefits, stock, insurance, ASU online school 100% covered.
cons: Absolutely no work life balance, it given enough labor to run efficiently and the way corporate wants us to. If upper management is visiting we are allowed to used 12+ hours more in labor to execute a dog and pony show which does not accurately reflect our day to day. DM’s can be awful and will micro manage you until you feel you can’t breathe. Having a supportive leader can really make you want to stay. However, having a power hungry boss will make you run far away. Do not recommend this job to anyone with anxiety because you will be in a constant state of worry and depression. The company constantly focuses on customer connections, but also wants you to see as many customers as you can in the shortest amount of time. All in all this company is a big hypocrite and so are the leaders in charge. Store managers do not get paid enough to work 60+ hour weeks, remain on call and effectively run a store while playing barista all day. You are forced to take your work home and no matter your how exhausted you are or if you have worked a 70 hour work week, if your store isn’t spotless and at 100 percent your boss will write you up and it will eventually lead to you being separated from the company.

job_title: Shift Supervisor in Maple Grove, MN
pros: The company truly cares about their workers and their well-being, especially throughout the pandemic. Flexible hours and yearly raises. There are also a lot of perks attributed to working at Starbucks, i.e. free drinks, free food, weekly free bagged coffee, 30% of food and drinks when not working, free online college, etc.
cons: Always understaffed and overworked. There has always been a hard time keeping workers from barista level to the store manager level. Within the 6 years I have been with the company, I have had around 10 store managers or interim managers running the store.

review_title: You deal with a lot, and the pay honestly isn't worth it.
job_title: Barista%2C Shift Supervisor in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Being able to transfer to other stores is pretty cool because you'll always have a job. I loved my coworkers until they all left. Have a lot of hours. Can have piercings, tattoos, and dyed hair.
cons: Standards for the company have gone down dramatically. It's gotten to the point that they are hiring anyone. Managers used to care about who they hired, and now employees are just numbers. This company definitely follows the "customer is always right" mantra about 95% of the time. Expected to just give the customer whatever they want because we have to get a certain Customer Connection score (i.e, customer satisfaction score), but this system is so rigged. If you aren't using this job for school, I recommend going a different route, at least until the company can get themselves together.

job_title: Shift Supervisor in Johnson City, TN
pros: the culture is fun and it's a very accepting place to work. lots of good benefits including spotify, health care for part time workers, free food and drinks, college program, and starbucks stock. flexible scheduling and vacation time. i've made a lot of life long friends working here.
cons: management in stores can be very hit or miss. it can also be frustrating because higher ups (district and general managers) have a lot more say over stores than you might think, and can tend to butt heads with store managers. company focus tends to bounce around a lot and can be confusing and frustrating for baristas (big focus on drive thru times, yet consistently releasing more and more complicated and time consuming beverages). very fast paced and stressful at times, and lots of hours on your feet. the company doesn't seem to like informing employees on promotions which results in understaffed and hectic promo days. dress code is a little intense for a coffee shop. pay is definitely not high enough for the level of stress and physical toll, and especially for long term partners who have shown dedication to the company, especially if you're not interested in moving up past a supervisor role. it tends to seem like the company values and safety precautions regarding COVID are more for show, and reminds me that at the end of the day it is a corporation, and profit will always come before the partners.

pros: The benefits were good and I drank a lot of coffee working there. I moved around a lot so it was great that I was able to transfer jobs all around the country.
cons:
Work culture is weird, a lot of young people tend to work at Starbucks so there is usually some drama this way or another. (aka Catty high school drama brought in to work)
Getting promoted is a popularity contest and working hard through merit is not how you get promoted.
Pay increases are garbage the longer you work there. You get a pay raise 1 or 2 times a year. So if let's say you started at $11 and then got a 60 cent raise, but after the minimum wage was raised to $12 you would just be making $12, the same as someone who just started there.
If a manager does something wrong they get a slap on the wrist and the corporation calls it a day. I had a manager sexually harass me and several other coworkers and when it was brought to corporate's attention and he was "investigated". Nothing happened.

pros:
I had many wonderful friendships with coworkers. They were my favorite part of the job, but that locational. My location was known for being close knit. There’s also three free drinks a day, and a free food item.
Starbucks had protected sick time, vacation hours you accumulated after one year, health insurance, and other employee benefits.
cons: Poor management, HAD to work weekends, hard to call in sick without a guilt trip, customers were allowed to verbally abuse you and got rewarded for it. Time off was never guaranteed, but yet neither were good hours. Would schedule you outside of availability, or during time you requested off because of low staffing. Staff was quitting because they were tired of the crap. Would let drunk homeless people camp out in the lobby, even though they sexually harassed several workers.

pros:
- Free drinks on shift
- 50% off food whilst on shift
- 30% off all items
- 1 free mark-out (Beans, pods, etc.) per week
cons:
It is difficult to list the cons as done in the pros. However, the employees higher up the chain, e.g. district managers and HR, do not seem to understand what work is like on the frontline in the stores. Should a customer treat you with disrespect, continuously, you are expected to absorb anything and everything they throw at you, standing your ground and looking out for other employees is a big no-no. 

Throughout COVID, we have remained open for the most part, putting ourselves at risk for the sake of some coffee. We are not provided PPE (i.e. facemasks) nor are we compensated for it, we have never been asked to provide a NEGATIVE COVID TEST, nor do they ever take employees temperatures. There are even cases of shuffling baristas between stores, some of which have had breakouts of COVID. Many days, it can be quite depressing in store, in a place that is normally packed. Yet, we are not allowed to read, play a simple COVID safe game. There is only so much cleaning that can be done before it becomes pointless, and quite frankly the company has little to no care for their staff, other than the money that they are bringing in, which in all honesty is not very much at all. The way we have been treated throughout the pandemic is disgusting.

review_title: Love the company, the customers could use some work
job_title: Shift Supervisor in San Pablo, CA
pros: Love my manager and my peers who do their best to support each other and be there for one another. Company offers good benefits, you're eligible for medical even if you're part time, and they even cover 20 free therapy sessions through a program called Lyra. Offered catastrophe pay for a couple months during the start of the pandemic, where you essentially got paid to stay at home. They also offered emergency sick pay if you contracted COVID, and give you paid time off to go get your vaccine. Flexible work schedule, you only need to be available for at least one weekend day. Easy to climb up the work ladder and get promoted if you are dedicated to your role and your team.
cons: Customers are very aware of company policies and many go out of their way to take advantage of you. We do our best to give people the benefit of the doubt, but a lot of people bear horrible attitudes towards customer service workers and act like they can walk all over you, no matter how nice or accommodating you are to them. You have to have a tough skin in order to work in customer service, and learn how to let things roll off your back.

pros: Competitive benefits for a minimum wage job. They offer insurance (if you work 20h/week) and will cover some of your tuition after you've been working there for 6 months. This is in addition to free bags of coffee/tea weekly, free drinks while working and a discount when not working. LGBTQ+ friendly.
cons: Constantly understaffed, employees often having to fill two if not three roles at a time. Cleaning tasks end up being inadequately done or neglected. You are overworked, everyone is always stressed. Customers are unusually aggressive. Internal promotions are nearly impossible to get. Schedules would get changed on us without notice.
